groundTruth.text: AbstractOrganized attempts to manipulate public opinion during election run-ups have dominated online debates in the last few years. Such attempts require numerous accounts to act in coordination to exert influence. Yet, the ways in which coordinated behavior surfaces during major online political debates is still largely unclear. This study sheds light on coordinated behaviors that took place on Twitter (now X) during the 2020 US Presidential Election. Utilizing state-of-the-art network science methods, we detect and characterize the coordinated communities that participated in the debate. Our approach goes beyond previous analyses by proposing a multifaceted characterization of the coordinated communities that allows obtaining nuanced results. In particular, we uncover three main categories of coordinated users: (i) moderate groups genuinely interested in the electoral debate, (ii) conspiratorial groups that spread false information and divisive narratives, and (iii) foreign influence networks that either sought to tamper with the debate or that exploited it to publicize their own agendas. We also reveal a large use of automation by far-right foreign influence and conspiratorial communities. Conversely, left-leaning supporters were overall less coordinated and engaged primarily in harmless, factual communication. Our results also showed that Twitter was effective at thwarting the activity of some coordinated groups, while it failed on some other equally suspicious ones. Overall, this study advances the understanding of online human interactions and contributes new knowledge to mitigate cyber social threats.

problem.title: Detecting and Characterizing Coordinated Influence Operations in Online Political Discourse in the US presidential election
problem.description: The challenge of systematically identifying, classifying, and understanding the dynamics of coordinated influence operations in digital public spheres, where groups of actors (domestic or foreign, human or automated) deliberately manipulate online debates while distinguishing between organic participation, malicious disinformation, and agenda-driven interference. This problem extends beyond elections to other polarized sociopolitical contexts (e.g., public health crises, geopolitical conflicts) and platforms (e.g., social media, forums, messaging apps).

templateData.title: Technical Framework for Detecting Coordinated Influence Operations in Digital Political Discourse
templateData.description: A structured template capturing technical methodologies, quantitative metrics, and implementation specifics for systematically identifying, classifying, and analyzing coordinated influence operations in online political discourse, with emphasis on reproducibility, scalability, and cross-platform adaptability.

templateProperty.label: Primary Dataset
templateProperty.description: Named dataset(s) used for training/evaluation, including platform origin (e.g., Twitter, Reddit, 4chan) and collection methodology (e.g., API, scraped, proprietary).

templateProperty.label: Data Collection Period
templateProperty.description: Start and end dates (ISO 8601 format) for raw data acquisition, including any temporal gaps or sampling intervals.

templateProperty.label: Coordination Detection Algorithm
templateProperty.description: Named algorithm or model architecture (e.g., GraphSAGE, Temporal Motif Detection, Hawkes Process) used to identify coordinated behaviors, including version/modifications.

templateProperty.label: Behavioral Features Extracted
templateProperty.description: List of quantitative features engineered for coordination detection (e.g., temporal alignment, content similarity, retweet graphs, burstiness metrics).

templateProperty.label: Ground Truth Labeling Method
templateProperty.description: Technique used for annotation (e.g., expert panels, crowdsourcing, platform-supplied labels, synthetic injection) and inter-annotator agreement metrics (e.g., Cohen’s kappa).

templateProperty.label: Class Imbalance Ratio
templateProperty.description: Ratio of organic-to-coordinated samples in the training/evaluation sets (e.g., 100:1). Critical for evaluating model robustness.

templateProperty.label: Temporal Resolution
templateProperty.description: Granularity of time-based analysis (e.g., second-level, hourly, daily) and justification for selection.

templateProperty.label: Graph Construction Method
templateProperty.description: Approach for building interaction graphs (e.g., retweet networks, reply chains, co-hashtag graphs) including edge weights and directionality rules.

templateProperty.label: Baseline Models
templateProperty.description: Named baseline methods (e.g., Botometer, Random Forest, LSTM) used for comparative evaluation, including versions and hyperparameters.

templateProperty.label: Precision@K
templateProperty.description: Precision at top-K ranked detections (e.g., P@10, P@100) for coordinated clusters, reported separately for domestic/foreign actors if applicable.

templateProperty.label: False Positive Analysis
templateProperty.description: Qualitative/quantitative breakdown of false positives (e.g., organic activism misclassified as coordination), including error modes and mitigation strategies.

templateProperty.label: Cross-Platform Validation
templateProperty.description: Description of adaptation steps and performance degradation (if any) when applying the method to platforms beyond the primary dataset (e.g., Telegram, Facebook).

templateProperty.label: Ethical Risk Mitigation
templateProperty.description: Technical safeguards implemented to prevent misuse (e.g., differential privacy, output sanitization, bias audits) and compliance with platform ToS/research ethics boards.

templateProperty.label: Reproducibility Package
templateProperty.description: URL to a containerized environment (e.g., Docker Hub, Dockerfile in repo) or Colab notebook with dependencies locked for full replication.

templateProperty.label: Dynamic Adversary Testing
templateProperty.description: Methods used to evaluate robustness against adaptive adversaries (e.g., simulated evasion tactics, A/B testing with perturbed features).

templateProperty.label: Real-Time Processing Latency
templateProperty.description: End-to-end latency (ms) for streaming detection pipelines, measured at 95th percentile under peak load (specify load parameters).

templateProperty.label: Multilingual Support Scope
templateProperty.description: Languages supported for content-based features (e.g., English, Spanish, Russian) and any performance degradation for non-primary languages.

templateProperty.label: Explainability Method
templateProperty.description: Technique used to generate human-interpretable explanations for detections (e.g., SHAP, LIME, attention weights, rule-based post-hoc analysis).

templateProperty.label: Cost per Analysis
templateProperty.description: Estimated computational cost (e.g., USD per 1M samples) for cloud-based deployment, including hardware and software licensing fees.

errors.comments: Couldn't understand the error in paper analysis phase. It would be nice to have full description why that error was thrown

stability.comments: Whole system was stable. Maybe bit slow for a first time user.

overall.comments: System has great potential and can be improved,.
Good. I have seen and used Research rabbit, perplexity, Litmap, Chatgpt. I thinkk ORKG has better potential and trust among exsisting tools.

manualHighlight.comments: Didn't know that feature exist but it could be nice to give that as pop-up orself guide tour in the beginning

overall.comments: Brilliant, can't wait to use it.
